results.title: Unearthing a Maya Civilization That ‘Punched Above Its Weight’
results.abstract: Before the pandemic, the long-sought ruins of Sak Tz’i’, a small but influential Mesoamerican kingdom, were discovered on a cattle ranch in Mexico. This summer archaeologists returned to excavate it.

media.caption: A stone panel, dating to the eighth century A.D., of K’ab Kante’, a ruler of the ancient Maya kingdom of Sak Tz’i’. The ruins of Lakanjá Tzeltal, a settlement at least 2,500 years old, were discovered in Chiapas, Mexico.

results.title: Expanded Safety Net Drives Sharp Drop in Child Poverty

results.title: U.S. Returns Rare Coin Minted by Jews During Rebellion From Rome
results.abstract: The silver quarter shekel, estimated to be worth as much as $1 million, was minted in the first century by Jews who created it as a statement of sovereignty during the uprising known as The Great Revolt.

media.caption: Experts say that this coin, dated to roughly A.D. 69, is among the rarest remaining from the Jewish uprising against imperial Rome. It is estimated to be worth $500,000 to $1 million.
